awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Biological Extraction and Purification of Rare Earth Elements
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the potential development of an environmentally friendly, biology-based technology to extract and purify rare earth elements (REE). REE are elements from the periodic table consisting of the lanthanides elements as well as scandium and yttrium. They are essential ingredients in important modern technologies such as computers and catalysts, as well as many clean energy technologies such as windmills and electric cars. Currently, there is limited mining and purification of these critical minerals undertaken in the US.  The proposed technology uses engineered bacteria to cleanly extract and purify REE from recycled and waste materials that are readily available in the US. Options for REE feedstocks include recycled electronics, coal ash, and various catalysts among other materials. 


This I-Corps project is based on the potential development of engineered bacteria capable of extracting and purifying rare earth elements (REE). The proposed technology uses the bacterium Gluoconobacter oxydans to produce an acidic biolixiviant capable of leaching REE into a solution from an REE-containing material. In addition, various strains of the bacteria Shewanella oneidensis are engineered to have binding sites on their membranes specific for a particular REE, which allows individual REEs to be adsorbed from a mixture. Individual REEs are then desorbed from the bacterial membranes to create a pure solution and precipitated from the solution as an oxide or carboxylate.  Results at lab scale have shown that the engineered bacteria may produce a biolixiviant that will leach REE out of a feedstock into solution with a reasonably high efficiency and the relative affinity on the bacterial membrane for REE may be modified to enhance purification.  The proposed technology may be used to extract and purify REE from waste such as coal ash as well as other feedstocks, providing a steady supply of REE.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Rare earth elements (REE) are essential components in sustainable energy technologies such as wind turbines, electric vehicles, high-temperature superconductors, and high-strength lightweight alloys. The demand for REE is projected to increase sevenfold by 2040. However, traditional methods for extracting and separating REE are highly environmentally damaging. Consequently, the global supply chain for REE is largely controlled outside of the United States. Developing a clean domestic supply chain for REE is crucial for advancing a clean energy economy both in the U.S. and globally.

We think that biotechnologies can replace some of the most environmentally-damaging steps in REE mining and refining, allowing us to operate a domestic supply chain for REE. My lab has developed genetically engineered microbes for REE-extraction from ore and end-of-life material, and for REE separations by selective biosorption. Two members of the Barstow lab at Cornell (Alexa Schmitz and Sean Medin) formed REEgen to commercialize this technology. 

The major goals of this project were twofold: (1) to test nine hypotheses regarding the U.S. rare earth market, and (2) to identify nine customer segments within this market. The insights gained from these objectives will help REEgen to refine its business model and enhance its chances of success.

 

Major Accomplishments

Market Visits and Objectives:

During the award period, Alexa Schmitz and Sean Medin visited REE suppliers and end-users across the United States. Their specific objectives included:

1. Stable U.S. Supply: CEOs of companies dependent on REE (e.g., magnet and catalyst manufacturers) expressed a desire for a stable U.S. supply of REE.

 2. Recycling Partnerships: Business development directors at recycling companies are seeking partners to handle REE-bearing waste.

 3. Coal Ash Utilization: Environmental directors of coal ash plants are willing to pay for the removal of coal ash.

 4. Mining Technology Needs: New companies exploring REE mining are looking for technologies to make REE extraction economically viable.

 5. Sustainability Concerns: VPs of sustainability dealing with fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) units identified landfilling as a significant economic drain.

 6. Regulatory Support: Environmental regulators indicated a willingness to quickly approve new beneficial uses of coal combustion residuals (CCR) if they serve national interests.

 7. Chemical Industry Demand: Purchasing managers at chemical companies need reliable sources for REE.

8. Value-Added Services: REE resellers are willing to pay a premium for custom impurity treatments.

 

Customer Segment Discovery:

The team confirmed the existence of the following customer segments:

1. CEOs of REE Alloy Companies: Interested in buying U.S.-sourced REE.

2. Directors of Procurement at Catalyst Companies: This segment exists.

3. Business Development Directors at Chemical/Alloy Companies: This segment exists.

4. Business Development Directors for Magnet Companies: This segment exists.

5. Companies Using Large Quantities of REE: This segment exists.

6. Companies Using Moderate Quantities of REE: This segment exists.

7. Companies Using Small Quantities of REE: This segment exists.

8. Directors of Operations at Recycling Companies: This segment exists, with light phosphors identified as a better source than e-waste.

9. Directors of Operations at Coal Mining Companies: This segment exists.

 

Training and Professional Development

The project provided valuable opportunities for market analysis and networking for Alexa Schmitz and Sean Medin. Both have transitioned from academic roles in the lab to leadership positions at REEgen, with Alexa serving as CEO and Sean as CTO. This experience has validated the lab’s approach to preparing students for entrepreneurial careers and has provided a template for future spin-out companies.

 

Future Plans

Moving forward, the team plans to adapt their REE separation technologies to better meet the needs of the U.S. market. This involves refining the biosorption/desorption processes for REE purification to enhance efficiency and cost-effectiveness.

 

Impact on the Field and Society

This project has advanced understanding of the key processes needed for lanthanide separation, which is crucial for building a domestic REE supply chain. The insights gained are likely to impact knowledge, theory, and research in the field of REE purification. Furthermore, the project has accelerated the development of human resources in science, engineering, and technology by preparing individuals like Alexa Schmitz and Sean Medin for leadership roles in the industry.

The project has also influenced educational experiences by integrating real-world problems into classroom settings, engaging students in developing models for REE separation using genetic engineering. This hands-on approach has provided students with a deep understanding of scientific problem-solving.

 

Technological and Societal Impact

By translating lab-developed biotechnologies for environmentally friendly REE extraction and separation into practical applications through REEgen, the project has significant potential for commercial technology transfer. It supports the development of a clean energy economy, which is essential for national and global sustainability efforts.
